description: The noun is derived from pin +â€Ž cushion. The verb is derived from the noun.

entries.meaning: (sewing) A device, originally like a small, stuffed cushion, designed to have sewing pins and needles stuck into it to store them safely; some modern pincushions hold the objects magnetically.

definitionGroups.group: The names of various plants with flowers or other parts resembling a pincushion.

entries.meaning: A flowering plant in the genus Leucospermum.
A flowering plant in the genus Scabiosa.
The coral bead plant, coral moss, or English baby tears (Nertera granadensis), an ornamental plant.
The dustymaiden, a flowering plant in the genus Chaenactis.
The pincushion cactus, of the genera Escobaria or Mammillaria.
The pincushionplant, a flowering plant in the genus Navarretia.
(figuratively, colloquial) A person who is pricked or stabbed multiple times with sharp objects; specifically, someone who receives regular hypodermic needle injections.

verbs.description: pincushion (third-person singular simple present pincushions, present participle pincushioning, simple past and past participle pincushioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, also figuratively) To jab or stick repeatedly with one or more sharp objects, as with pins into a pincushion.
examples: The target was pincushioned with arrows.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To assume the shape of a pincushion; specifically, of the image on a computer display, television, etc., to exhibit pincushion distortion, where the sides curve inwards.
